DOC.HEAD: Trump Shuttle Reaches Contract Agreement with Pilots
EDS: New grafs 3-6 to UPDATE with head of pilots union predicting ratification, noting difference from Eastern contract talks; picks up 5th graf pvs bg'ng, The Trump ...; ADDS byline
DOC.TEXT: The Trump Shuttle, the northeast airline service named after the billionaire developer who bought it six months ago, has reached a collective bargaining agreement with the pilots union. The 4-year agreement, which must be ratified by the rank and file, provides for improvements in wages, benefits and work rules, the airline said Tuesday. Trump Shuttle spokeswoman Joan Fudala declined to give any details. ``I don't think there's any doubt that it will be ratified,'' Les Robinson, head of the pilots union at the airline, said in a telephone interview. He also declined to disclose details of the tentative agreement. Ray Grebey, the shuttle's chief labor negotiator, said in a statement the new agreement ``recognizes the unique nature of hourly shuttle operations''. Most of the 225 pilots at Trump Shuttle, which links New York with Boston and Washington, formerly worked for Eastern Airlines. Wealthy property developer Donald Trump bought the shuttle service from Miami-based Eastern for $365 million in early June. ``We are not any longer working for a have-not airline,'' Robinson said. Calling the brief contract negotiations ``a real love-in,'' he said they were markedly different from the ``Eastern tradition'' of adversarial relations between employees and management. The Trump Shuttle pilots are members of the Air Line Pilots Association, one of three unions that struck Eastern last March, forcing it to seek bankruptcy court reorganization. The Eastern pilots and flight attendants halted their strikes shortly before Thanksgiving, but the Machinists union is continuing its walkout. Contract negotiations covering the 280 flight attendants at Trump Shuttle are due to start in the first quarter of next year, Ms. Fudala said. Talks with the Machinists union have been postponed pending a challenge from a rival group, the Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association, which is seeking to represent mechanics at the shuttle.
